MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - New Dublin Hospital.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if the plans for the proposed new St. James Hospital, Dublin have been sanctioned; and, if so, if they also include a dental teaching facility.

My function in relation to the planning of St. James Hospital relates to the planning of the general hospital and I have approved of the planning brief for the hospital. The design team are now engaged in the detailed planning of the project.

The Minister for Education has decided to locate the proposed new dental teaching facility for Dublin on the St. James Hospital site but the plans for this facility will be dealt with separately and not as part of the plans for the general hospital.
Will the Minister state if the plans for teaching facilities have been approved?
Any question about the new dental teaching facility for Dublin on the St. James Hospital site should be addressed to the Minister for Education.
In other words the Minister cannot say.
The Minister has no responsibility to say.
The hospital board will be very interested to hear that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Infant Sudden Deaths.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will make any moneys available for research into the causes of sudden deaths in infants.

Research into the cause of sudden death on non-specific cause in infancy is at present being carried out by the Department of Community Health in Trinity College, Dublin. I intend to ask the Medico-Social Research Board to assess the feasibility and need for carrying out further research into the incidence and causes of such deaths.
Is the Minister prepared to make any funds available to the medical bodies who are carrying out research into the causes of sudden deaths in infants?
Yes.
Will it be this year?
As the need arises.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Health Education Bureau.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if a new director of the Health Education Bureau has been appointed; and, if so, the method and terms of appointment.

The Health Education Bureau appointed a director on 9 January 1978. The appointment was made after an open competition and is whole-time, permanent and pensionable, subject to the normal probationary arrangements. The salary is within the range £7,220 to £8,720.
Will the Minister state if the advice of the Health Education Council in Britain was sought or offered in the appointment of the director?
I doubt if it was but I am not in a position to state categorically that it was not. As far as I know it was not.
I have a letter from them stating that they did advise on the selection of a director.
We all know that the director was the head of the Fianna Fáil health think-tank when the Minister was in Opposition.
I am not saying that. I am just saying I was surprised to note in a letter from them that they did advise.
The Deputy must be joking. The person appointed was the Minister's chief adviser when Fianna Fáil were in Opposition.
Of course that does not take away from his ability.
Not at all.
I want to assure the House that I had no hand, act or part in the selection of the new director.
I am very happy to know that.
I had no hand, act or part except to approve the appointment when it came before me.
It was a very happy coincidence.
It may well be a coincidence but I can assure the Deputy that what I said was true. I had no hand, act or part in the selection process.
He would have got higher remuneration elsewhere.

I have a note here which says that the bureau nominated the chairman and three other members, Professor Burke, Mr. Delaney and Mr. O'Dwyer to the interview panel. It also arranged to have Dr. Gleeson, President of the IMA, on the panel. I can assure the House I was not in any way involved.
It is a case of “here's Harry” who just happened to fall into the slot.

It is quite immaterial to me whether the Deputy accepts my word for it or not. I am making the statement that I was not involved in any way until the name came before me in the final stages for approval.
I am entitled to dis-believe that——
The Deputy is entitled to do that. He is probably confusing this Government with the practices indulged in so comprehensively by our predecessors.
The Minister had a fair amount of practice——
I am calling the next question.
asked the Minister for Health if an advisory committee to the Health Education Bureau has been established; and, if so, its composition.
An advisory committee has not been established. The possible establishment of such a committee is being reviewed in the context of broader proposals for community health.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Wheelchair Users' Facilities.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health whether he will take steps to have public transport vehicles modified so as to facilitate wheelchair users.

I appreciate the problems which wheelchair users have in using public transport vehicles and I will discuss with my colleagues the Ministers for the Environment and for Tourism and Transport what steps, if any, might be taken in relation to public transport vehicles to facilitate wheelchair users.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hospital Consultant's Payment Report.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health when the report of the Finlay Commission on payment to hospital consultants will be published.

The interim report of the review body was submitted to me on 20 January and the necessary arrangements have been made to have copies of the report available to interested parties. In fact, since I drafted that reply it has been made available to practically everyone who might be interested.

Would the Minister care to comment on the fact that it has taken four years to produce what I consider to be a very ambiguous and useless document? Does he consider they should have spent all that time and money in producing that document? What are his comments on the matter?

The only comment I would make is that I would not agree with the Deputy's comments. The Deputy will have to admit that the work of the committee to a large extent was overshadowed by political developments.

Is the Minister aware that this working party travelled to Canada, Scotland and Europe at great public expense? They then produced a woolly document consisting of a few pages. From what the Minister has said it appears he has not read it——
The Deputy knows I have read it.
I am surprised the Minister does not agree with my comments. He knows in his heart that it is a very bad document having regard to all the work and money involved.
I would point out that it is an interim report.
Is the Minister in agreement with the recommendations in the report?
The Deputy should put down a question.
That is not in the original question.
The Minister will not say whether he is in agreement with the recommendations.

The report is still under consideration. It is only an interim report and, to a large extent, the work of that body has been over-taken by events. The body was set up to come forward with a scheme in the context of total free hospitalisation.
The Minister will not give his views.
The committee has produced an interim report in the context of a situation which is no longer applicable.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Combat Poverty Committee.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he vetoed a Combat Poverty Committee proposal to establish a fish farm at Castletown-bere, County Cork as part of its community action project; and the reason for any such action.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Haughey) Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Haughey)
Speaker.P: I received no such proposal from the National Committee on Pilot Schemes to Combat Poverty.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Social Welfare Benefit Qualifications.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if persons employed by Butlins during the summer season have the required number of stamps paid to qualify them for benefit; and if so, why their benefit has not been paid.
Only one of the persons referred to in the question failed to satisfy the contribution conditions for entitlement to unemployment benefits.

In addition to satisfying the contribution conditions, however, claimants to unemployment benefit must also satisfy the condition that they are available for employment. A number of these claimants had their claims for benefit disallowed under the latter condition on the ground that they were not available for employment other than as seasonal workers with Butlins in Mosney, County Meath. They were notified of their right to appeal against these decisions and of 19 who did so all but three had their claims allowed by Appeals Officers following oral hearings of their cases. Benefit has been paid to all those whose claims were successful.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Single Women's Allowance.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will provide for all single women who have to stay at home, or leave their employment to look after aged or sick parents or relatives an allowance on par with that paid to widows, deserted wives, and so on, in addition to a credited class 1 insurance stamp to ensure that they are in benefit when re-entering employment or on reaching pensionable age.

Under present arrangements, where an incapacitated person aged 66 or over is receiving full-time care and attention from a prescribed relative, an increase of pension or benefit may be payable to that person. In such cases also the prescribed relative, if previously insured, may be awarded credited contributions to ensure continuity of insurance coverage. Alternatively from age 58 a single woman may, if she satisfies a means test, qualify for social assistance allowance which may be paid until attainment of pensionable age. These provisions are reviewed from time to time but no change is at present contemplated.
Did the Minister say that they may qualify for a stamp?
They do.
They do qualify.
Might I ask the Minister if that fact is widely known?
I could not say.
That is the point. Could the Minister tell me in what document details of this are available?
Is it the stamp aspect to which the Deputy is referring?
Yes. The Minister might consider making the fact that they can obtain this credit more widely known.
Is the Deputy suggesting that there is some widespread lack of understanding of the situation?
Yes.
I was not aware of that.
The Minister mentioned something about increases for an old person in respect of somebody staying at home. Are they meant to pay for the stamp? Is it the idea that the old person pays for the stamp?
No. If the prescribed relative was previously insured he or she may be awarded credited contributions to ensure continuity.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Social Welfare Forms Availability.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will make SW 54 forms readily available to the public through dispensaries, post-offices and so on.

Supplies of the information leaflet SW 54 which gives details of the Supplementary Welfare Allowances Scheme have been distributed to almost a thousand health centres throughout the country. The leaflet is also available at all information offices of my Department and at the community information centres registered with the National Social Service Council.
What about post offices?
Perhaps the Deputy would leave it until Question No. 27 because the same issue comes up then and I shall be dealing with it more fully there.
Could the Minister say if the figure of 1,000 is the total number?
One thousand health centres.
Is that the total number of health centres, or is it 1,000 out of——
All health centres.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Social Welfare Complaints.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the number of written complaints his Department have received about the operation of the social welfare system in the last year to the latest available date.
Records are not kept in such a way as to enable the information sought by the Deputy to be given.
Do I take it, when complaints come to the Department of Social Welfare, they are assigned to the wastepaper basket?
Oh, no.

The reply suggests that. It should be possible to have a record of complaints received. If the Department does not have a record the only conclusion I can come to—and indeed that to which the public and the House can come to—is that they are assigned to the wastepaper basket.
No, they are dealt with, replied to.
Slowly.
Would the Minister agree it might be a good idea to know the number of complaints received by his Department?

As the Deputy knows, in a Department like the Department of Social Welfare, complaints of this type are an everyday occurrence, are dealt with as far as possible and replies issued to them. I do not know if enumeration of the number of these complaints would be of any particular value. The important thing is to try to deal with them, give satisfaction, and make sure that any genuine causes for complaints are eliminated.

Yes, but surely the Minister would agree that unless his Department have some indication of the number of complaints, they will not be in a position to remedy them all. Dealing with complaints on an individual basis is not necessarily the best answer whereas one may resolve a lot of the problems in the Department of Social Welfare by having information as to the type of complaint most frequently received. I would hope that the Minister would consider it in that light.

As a matter of fact I saw some figures which would indicate that there are 10,000 communications per week to the Department. Some of those would be more in the nature of enquiries rather than complaints.
I am asking only about complaints.

I know but, as a rule, it is very difficult to distinguish between them. In this connection I have asked for correspondence over a period to be analysed to see what is the nature of the most persistent complaints.
That is it.
That will be a help to us. The correspondence is very voluminous, plus the telephone calls.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Social Welfare Entitlements.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the training, if any, that is being provided at present to those officers in his Department who are in the first line of contact with the public seeking social welfare entitlements.

Officers in my Department who are in the first line of contact with the public seeking social welfare entitlements are given appropriate training and instruction in the administration of the legislation governing these entitlements and, in particular, in the importance of helpfulness, courtesy and consideration in dealing with members of the public.

Is the Minister aware that there is a considerable degree of concern amongst those people who apply for benefits that they are not receiving the attention they deserve? Is the Minister further aware that I telephoned the information department of the Department of Social Welfare about a particular aspect of some problem and was told they could not answer it; they suggested I telephone another number. If I was forced to do that would the Minister not consider it a lot more troublesome to members of the public who would be told to do so? Would that information not contradict that in the Minister's brief there?
The Deputy is falling into the habit of—
Asking questions.
Of making speeches.

I support what Deputy Dr. O'Connell suggested—that some inquiry should be made. Could the Minister ensure that these people are informed that, when they are allocating funds, they are awarded by the public, are subscribed to by the people who are getting them in the form of rates and taxes, that they do not come out of the assistants' or officers' pockets personally, which is the attitude held in a number of cases.
That is a separate question.
That is a very important aspect.
The question relates to persons in the first line of contact.
Poor law is gone.
It is a very important matter, one in which I am very interested, to ensure that, at all times, courtesy and helpfulness prevail.
Hear, hear.

I know from experience, not through the Department of Social Welfare alone but throughout Departments generally, that it is difficult to get away from an attitude of former years in which the public servant felt that it was his duty to husband public funds to the greatest possible extent and release them only when there was no other course available. Certainly the official attitude in the Department of Social Welfare, and indeed in the Department of Health, is that if a member of the general public is entitled to something, he is so entitled and is not under any compliment to anybody; it is his statutory right as a citizen. I think most people in the Department understand that. It is difficult, I suppose, to ensure that, at all times the right, courteous, helpful, patient attitude prevails.

Would the Minister consider seminars for these people? Secondly, would he make available officers of his Department to attend meetings of associations such as ADAPT who would be in need of such advice and information, in this way making information available on what is these people's entitlement? I have asked the Minister's Department if they would provide an officer to attend such meetings for this purpose and they refused. Would the Minister consider that it could form part of the general public education?
I agree it is a very necessary function of my Department to attend all possible meetings and disseminate information.
Could the Minister issue a directive to that effect?
Yes. I would have thought that was understood by every-body concerned.
Unfortunately, it is not taking place on the ground.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Social Surveys.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the social surveys that have been undertaken by his Department in the last three years.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare if any survey has been undertaken by his Department on the number of people living below subsistence level in Ireland.
With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Question Nos. 17 and 18 together.

A number of surveys have been undertaken in the last three years by the National Committee on Pilot Schemes to Combat Poverty. The surveys were designed to provide basic information about less well-off sections of the community as well as the services which provide for their needs.

In addition, I have approved a grant by the committee to the Society of St. Vincent de Paul for a national survey of old persons living alone. A complementary study on the elderly is being carried out by the Economic and Social Research Institute and I also propose making a grant to the Institute towards the cost of their survey.
The surveys I have mentioned are part of a continuing programme in the field of poverty and are in various stages of completion.
Would the Minister be in a position to say if a survey is being undertaken into the number of people living below subsistence level in Ireland? That is the specific query in question No. 18.
That would come mainly under the survey which would be carried out by the Economic and Social Research Institute.
Would the Minister be able to give a figure as to the number of people living below subsistence level in Ireland?

I am sure I will. Certainly I will have a lot more, particularly when the Economic and Social Research Institute report is completed. On the other hand, I am very interested also in the St. Vincent de Paul survey because I would hope that would answer questions which cannot be quantified strictly in statistical terms.
But it is a specific one related only to the problem of the aged.
People living alone.
Whereas I am speaking generally of people living below subsistence level: could we have some figure as to how many there are in Ireland today?
I will see what we can get on that.
Would the Minister let me know.
Yes, and if I do not, the Deputy can return to the attack with another question in due course.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Social Welfare Expenditure.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the percentage of Exchequer spending on social welfare benefits in each of the last five years.
With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to have the reply, which is in the form of a tabular statement, circulated with the Official Report.
Following is the statement:
EXCHEQUER contribution as a percentage of expenditure on benefits from the Social Insurance Fund.

MainHeading.P: NOTE: Social welfare benefits are taken to be benefits paid out of the Social Insurance Fund, the deficit on which is made up by the Exchequer.

Speaker.P: Could the Minister indicate whether the percentage has been static or has been increasing or decreasing over the period involved?
It has been fluctuating considerably.
The Deputy may not pursue a question answered by tabular statement.
Could he indicate whether the percentage——
The Chair will not permit me to elaborate on a tabular statement.
In my indulgence I permitted the Deputy to ask a casual question.
Is the percentage fluctuating on an upward trend?

I do not understand why a question, replied to by way of tabular statement—which conveniently obviates the necessity of the Minister giving the answer orally in the House —cannot be pursued by way of supplementary questions.
I am merely going by Standing Orders.
There is precedent for it.
I suspect the Chair is protecting the Deputy because the answer will not be too satisfactory from his point of view.
I am endeavouring to find out whether the percentage for 1978 will represent an increase on that for 1977.
I could not give the Deputy that kind of information because that percentage is not yet established.
Of course the Minister could because we all know it is going to be a decrease.

It is not yet established. If the Deputy knows that, he knows more than the Government. I can tell the Deputy that between 1973-74 and 1977 it went down from 30 per cent to 19 per cent under the jurisdiction of the Deputy's party.
It is extraordinary.
From 30 per cent to 19 per cent.
Will the Minister make a statement?
I am perfectly prepared to do so but the Ceann Comhairle will not let me.
The Minister offered to make a statement but——

Under the Fine Gael-dominated Coalition the percentage went down from 30 per cent in 1973-74 to 19 per cent in 1977. I am sorry, a Cheann Comhairle, that you could not protect the Deputy from that devastating piece of information.
What is the percentage for 1978?
It is not yet settled.
Was it fixed yesterday?
It was not fixed yesterday. The Deputy does not understand the procedures.
I am not going to get another lecture from the Minister——
I have given the Deputy a devastating statistic. I am not giving him a lecture.
We all remember what happened to the Minister the last time he started to give an economic lecture to anyone.
The Deputy keeps interrupting and I am endeavouring to answer.
Next question.
(Interruptions.)

I am endeavouring to facilitate the House by giving the maximum possible information in reply to these questions and this obstreperous Deputy keeps interrupting me with a barrage of harassment and bad manners.
I object to the Minister speaking about me in this way. I am asking questions which I am entitled to ask. I do not see why he should make that sort of remark.
So far as I could hear, I think the Deputy was making some derogatory remarks about me in my capacity as Minister for Finance some years ago, which I am not now.
The Minister must have been listening to another Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Income-Related Pension Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the number of submissions which his Department have received on the introduction of a national income-related pension scheme; from whom the submissions were received; if a closing date has been set for submissions; and if a time-table has been established for the introduction of the scheme.

Would the Minister ensure that we have as widespread a number of submissions as possible? Would he make an announcement well in advance of the closing date in order to encourage more people to make submissions?
